title: The search for the body of a man seen submerging in Darwin Harbour | ABC NEWS
description: The search for the body of a man that was spotted floating in Darwin harbour before vanishing over the weekend has expanded.  The operation now includes land, sea and air vessels, with police calling for help to solve the mystery of who the man is. Joseph Hathway-Wilson has this report for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Concerns over rise in Islamaphobia after Bondi terror attack | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian National Imams Council has recorded an almost 200% increase in reported anti-Muslim hate since the Bondi Beach attack. Incidents include vandalism at Islamic institutions, online abuse, and physical intimidations. NSW Premier Chris Minns has condemned Islamophobic acts as "shameful", the state government renewing calls for unity. title: Sydney prepares for NYE fireworks with bolstered police presence | ABC NEWS
description: A record number of police officers will be on patrol in Sydney as the city prepares to celebrate New Year's Eve just weeks after the Bondi terror attack. Some officers will be carrying long-arm weapons. Authorities say there is no active or imminent threat to the public, but safety is the priority. title: Severe Tropical Cyclone Hayley crosses Western Australia's Kimberley coast | ABC NEWS
description: Residents in Western Australia's far north are sheltering in the midst of severe Tropical Cyclone Hayley, after it made landfall hours ahead of forecast. Nathan McIvor from the Djarindjin Aboriginal Corporation joined Manny Tsigas while weathering the storm at his house, which he says began to move as the conditions intensified. title: Re-Spin: Molly Picklum is a champion to behold
description: In this interview from the archives, Molly Picklum calls in from Fiji to talk about partying in a wetsuit, the big names who reached out to congratulate her, how she steeled herself after an early stumble in the final, how she wants to dominate the sport for years to come and tequila. If you want to hear what it sounds like for a 22-year-old surfer to realise her dream in Hawaii, then this is the episode for you. Try and listen to this without smiling. Featured: Molly Picklum, surfing world champion.   Subscribe to the ABC Sport Newsletter (https://www.abc.net.au/connect)

title: CIA reportedly carried out strike on Venezuelan port | ABC NEWS
description: Reports from US media have emerged that the CIA is responsible for a strike on a port facility in Venezuela. US President Donald Trump had previously flagged the attack before a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjmain Netanyahu, claiming the facility was used to load boats with drugs.  The move marks the first US strike on a Venezuelan land target amid simmering tensions between Washington and Caracas.  The Trump administration has been carrying out military strikes on alleged drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean and the Pacific Ocean, as it ramps up pressure on Venezuelan Nicolas Maduro to resign. title: Heavy rain batters Western Australia and Queensland’s north | ABC NEWS
description: Tropical Cyclone Hayley has battered the northern coast of Western Australia, while heavy rain and powerful winds slammed Queensland’s north.  The storm system is causing damage to property and trees as it moving inland over the West Kimberley, while one man has died in floodwaters in North Queensland.  The Bureau of Meteorology’s Miriam Bradbury says the storm is expected to weaken but is likely to bring further strong winds and heavy rainfall. title: Danish postal service becomes first national service to end letter deliveries | ABC NEWS
description: Denmark's postal service has ended its letter delivery service after 401 years in operation.  PostNord says there's been a 90 per cent decline in letter sending in favour of electronic communications, and the service needs to focus on parcel deliveries. title: Israel suspends dozens of aid groups in Gaza | ABC NEWS
description: Israeli authorities are suspending more than two dozen humanitarian agencies operating in Gaza, citing non-compliance with their new regulations. Israel is accusing about 15 per cent of aid organisations in the enclave of having links with Hamas, showing unfavourable views on Israel or failing to clarify the roles of some staff.  Doctors Without Borders (Médecins Sans Frontières) and Oxfam are among the aid groups which will be forced to cease all operations on the strip from January 1st, 2026.  MSF’s Ashley Killeen says registering an aid service in Gaza with the Israeli government is an ‘opaque process’.
